Award.AwardTitle: BRIGE: Understanding Multiphase Architecture in Li-ion Batteries through Multiscale Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ECCS-1125588
PI: FuqiangLiu
Institution: University of Texas at Arlington
Title: BRIGE: Understanding Multiphase Architecture in Li-ion Batteries through Multiscale Modeling

ABSTRACT

Intellectual Merit: The research objective of this BRIGE project is to explore the multiphase architecture of Li-ion battery electrodes through an integrated multiscale modeling approach. Such studies will reveal limitation of the electrode transport processes in greater details and thus provide strategies on how to improve the sluggish species transport and therefore battery capacity. In pursue of the goals, the planned research activities include: (1) developing a 3D multiscale model of transport, electrochemical reaction, and phase transformation in Li-ion electrode materials. The single-cell continuum convection-diffusion model, stochastic microstructure reconstruction, structure-level statistical analysis, single particle phase transformation, and experimental validation will be coupled together; and (2) predicting electrochemical behavior of numerically reconstructed electrodes and validating the model with ex situ and in situ experiments. The validated multiscale model will be applied to in-depth exploration and quantification of the battery electrode architectures reconstructed from SEM/TEM images.

Broader Impacts: The planed research will provide a heretofore inaccessible, microscopic insight to the multiphase architectures of Li-ion battery electrodes. Results of this work will result in a significant leap in further development of novel structures and processes for efficient energy storage. The proposed research efforts are integrated with education activities, which target both graduate and undergraduate students, but also high school students as well as minority and underrepresented groups (female, African American, Hispanic and disabled). Hispanic students, which are the fastest growing student segment at the University of Texas at Arlington, will be recruited to attend summer programs, and the PI will mentor them for academic careers in the field of engineering and energy. A suite of interactive numerical models for use in a variety of courses will be created. A combined effort of an interactive virtual nano-energy simulation database and experimental demonstration library will be set up to showcase the research and fully immerse students in the discovery process that defines science and engineering. An interactive summer camp on Electrochemical Energy for K-12 students, in conjunction with the Web-based virtual laboratory, will be developed to raise students awareness in the area of energy storage and to keep them motivated in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

High-capacity Li-ion batteries are among the most viable candidates for next generation, clean, and potentially fossil fuel independent electric vehicles. The main factor limiting Li-ion battery performance is sluggish species transport—both electronic and ionic—in a multiphase electrode architecture. In this project, the multiphase architecture of the battery electrode structure has been explored using an integrated multiscale modeling approach.

Specifically, the following tasks have been completed under this project: a) An 1D multiscale model including species transport, electrochemical reaction, and phase transition in electrode materials, and a 3D direct numerical simulation model were developed to study electrochemical transport processes in Li-ion battery electrodes. b) Detailed electrochemical discharge reactions have been studied and visualized on numerically reconstructed electrodes. c) Bing successfully validated using both conventional battery discharge curves and real-time Li salt at the electrode surface measured by in situ Raman spectroscopy, the models were able to predict electrochemical behaviors (including discharge capacity and voltage) of a Li-ion battery with electrodes of specific composition and structures.

Intellectual Merits: (1) This project has developed reconstructing algorithm of battery electrode microstructures and performed structure-level simulation on the reconstructed electrodes. The pore-scale electrochemical transport processes have been precisely pinpointed. (2) Critical interrelationships between macro-physical properties and nanoscale structural details were established directly from the Stochastic structure reconstruction, thus eliminating the burden of complex experimental characterization. (3) A fully integrated multiscale model, linking different length scales, surface properties, nanoscale transport, and electrochemical kinetics, allowed physics-based investigation of multiscale transport phenomena for the first time. (4) Furthermore, the work under this project has established an essential modeling framework for fundamental understanding of all other electrochemical energy systems, such as high performance fuel cells, photoelectrochemical cells, and supercapacitors.

Broader impact: This project (1) enhanced ongoing graduate research programs on energy storage and generation by providing new tools of particle-level modeling techniques to the study of energy conversion processes; (2) attracted, encouraged, and supported outstanding undergraduate students to attend conferences and pursue PhD studies; (3) integrated the outcomes of this project into community outreach activities; and (4) promoted education of female and minority students.
